Apr 6

Xbox Gamepass is the Netflix of Gaming

Xbox is releasing a service called Xbox Game Pass, which will offer a catalogue of over 100 games for $10 a month, similar to how Netflix offers a catalogue of movies and television for $8 a month.

In the same way Netflix has been proven to kill DVD sales, Xbox Game Pass will be just one step closer to a gaming industry free of physical media.

The move by Xbox was not unexpected. Playstation has a similar service called Playstation Now, at a higher price tag of $20 a month with a larger library of more than 450 games. Yet Playstation Now only has games from the previous generation, while Xbox Game Pass will offer current generation titles.

Xbox Game Pass stores the entire game onto the hard drive while Playstation Now uses a cloud-based service, meaning Xbox gamers won’t have to worry about streaming or bandwidth issues.

The Game Pass is an excellent way to compete against Playstation, which has been dominating Xbox since launch. Xbox One is behind by more than 20 million units in comparison to Playstation 4, which is still the top selling console of 2017.

Gaming industries often copy ideas that work. This can be seen most recently with Nintendo, as they have recently announced they will be charging a monthly fee for their online services like Playstation and Xbox.

The $10 a month price tag for a catalogue of over 100 games appeals to casual gamers who want something to play but don’t want to shell out $90 for a new game. That being said, it also appeals to avid gamers who want to take advantage of the catalogue without putting a dent in their wallets.

Xbox announced the Game Pass will not be available for PC. This is an effort to blur the lines between PC and Xbox and entice notoriously stubborn PC gamers to buy a console.

Xbox hasn’t released the full catalogue, but some of the confirmed games include Halo 5, Lego Batman, Mega Man Legacy Collection, and Saints Row IV. These are all excellent games, but they aren’t the $90 triple A titles behind the glass at your local game shop; these are the $20 value bin games.

Xbox is inadvertently making the used game market obsolete. Would you rather pay $10 for access to all these games or pay $20 a piece?

If consumers are able to play an entire catalogue of popular games for a $10 a month subscription, they will be less willing to pay full price for individual games or for the hard copy in retail stores.

For instance, if you have a Netflix subscription, you have access to every season of the popular TV show Breaking Bad. With that in mind, would you shell out $90 for the box set?

Similar to Netflix, Microsoft will eventually offer Game Pass exclusives. Phil Spencer, the head of Xbox, said in an interview with Engadget, “I would actually like to see this grow into a program where you can see frontline games and first shipped games come into Xbox Game Pass as a way to get distributed.”

Spencer says this can be seen in the TV sector with Netflix. At first, Netflix was filled with shows that have already run, but now some of the best TV shows are Netflix originals.

The high-quality exclusives aired by Netflix attract a large number of people to the service. If Xbox releases high-quality triple A titles exclusively on the Game Pass, gamers will undoubtedly flock to the service.

The games downloaded off the Game Pass will be available for as long as the subscription is active. If the subscription is cancelled or the customer fails to pay, the games are automatically deleted. Games will roll in and roll out of the Xbox Game Pass periodically, and it still requires an Xbox Live membership in order to use online services.

When the games are rolled out of the Game Pass, they will be available for purchase on the Xbox store. In other words, when the game becomes unavailable, it has to be bought at full price. However, people with the Game Pass will receive 20 per cent off.

This comes at a good time for Microsoft: after the record-breaking Nintendo Switch sales. According to Nintendo of Japan, they sold 330,637 units in its first three days on sale in Japan. This is not too far off from the first week sales of the Playstation 4 at 425,000 units sold in the United States. Unlike the Playstation 4, released during Christmas, the Nintendo Switch rolled out in early March. At this rate, if Nintendo Switch keeps up the momentum, they could outsell the Xbox One in sales by the end of the year.

Most families won’t purchase more than one console for their children at Christmas time. If families are buying the Nintendo Switch this Christmas, they probably won’t buy the Xbox One.

This probably doesn’t scare Microsoft. There is another Xbox in the works, codenamed Project Scorpio. There is evidence this could be the last “generation” of Xbox. It could be the all in one console that is here to stay.

Xbox has been pushing for heavier emphasis on system updates and digital downloads instead of system replacements. Aaron Greenberg, the head of Xbox’s game marketing said, “For us, we think the future is without console generations.”

A subscription-based gaming service in the style of Netflix is a good move for Microsoft in a time when they are lagging behind Playstation. Although, making a service like this is encouraging gamers to adopt a digital library instead of a physical library, and having a large body of games at all times would keep casual gamers afloat without the need to buy new games.

This raises questions about the future of the gaming industry. As companies gradually push to be more environmentally friendly, which gaming giant will be the first to drop the physical copy?
